snippet: The Constitution guarantees full powers for a representative legislature, the right to ownership of private property, and freedoms of speech, press and assembly.
abstract: Prominent Chinese intellectuals and publications are urging Communist Party to enforce principles contained within country's Constitution which was ratified in 1982, but has largely been ignored; strategy reflects emerging consensus among advocates for political reform that taking moderate stand in support of Constitution is best way to persuade Xi Jinping to open up China's party-controlled system.

byline.original: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD

lead_paragraph: The Constitution guarantees full powers for a representative legislature, the right to ownership of private property, and freedoms of speech, press and assembly.

headline.seo: Reformers Aim to Get China to Live Up to Own Constitution
headline.main: Reformers Aim to Get China to Live Up to Own Constitution
headline.print_headline: Reformers Aim to Get China to Live Up to Own Constitution
